Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Language Variation and Change in the Geographies of Suburbs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
More than 50% of Americans live in suburban areas. However, linguists studying language variation and change typically treat cities and suburbs as a uniform metropolitan area. This project takes the position that if we do not understand patterns of language variation and change in suburbs -- whether along geographical, demographic, or ideological lines -- we do not understand patterns of variation and change in the US. It seeks to build on previous sociolinguistic work both in suburbs and larger urban areas, with a research question of how language use and language change in suburban areas relates to patterns found in cities.

This project uses the St. Louis metropolitan area, a site well-known for its extensive suburbanization and White flight, as a case study. Eighty-four participants, twenty-eight each from a neighborhood in the City of St. Louis, a suburb that developed in the 1930s, and a suburb that developed through urban sprawl in the 1970-1980s, will complete a questionnaire and engage in a sociolinguistic interview, including a word list and reading passage. Acoustic analysis of several vowels obtained in the interview and elicitations will be used alongside the questionnaire data to ascertain linguistic patterns in suburbs.
This project brings the sociolinguistic literature into conversation with current approaches to metropolitan areas in other fields. Additionally, it contributes to understanding the role that federal and local housing policy have played in patterns of suburbanization and residential segregation. The US has only recently begun to grapple with the impacts of these policies (see, for example, the 2014 protests in the St. Louis suburb of Ferguson, Missouri), and this project extends research on their impacts to the linguistic and cultural realms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Daniel Duncan completed research for his dissertation "Language variation and change in the geographies of suburbs" supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement grant. During his funding period, he spent nine months in the Greater St. Louis area conducting interviews with white, middle-class locals about their experiences living in the area, before returning to NYU to analyze his data and write his dissertation.

These interviews form the basis of his dissertation, completed in 2018. He used the audio recordings to obtain data about the local dialect and how it has changed in recent decades. His findings show that as in many other US cities, some traditionally distinctive features of the St. Louis dialect are disappearing among younger speakers. This phenomenon is being led by speakers in the suburbs, a finding which contributes new knowledge about how traditional features disappear.

More generally, Duncan's research finds that although speakers in the Greater St. Louis area talk like one another in many ways, suburban development and urban sprawl play a role in influencing the local dialect. The white St. Louis pronunciation of the vowel in words like cat, for example, spread to suburban St. Charles County only after suburbanization began in earnest in the 1970s. The interviews he conducted show that perhaps a more important role is played by how speakers identify with the region. Suburbanites who identity with the suburbs, for example, are more likely to work close to home, while those who do not are more likely to commute towards the city. This lifestyle choice influences how they speak: those who commute speak more similarly to those from the city than those who do not commute. These findings show the relevance of suburbs to linguistic variation, something which has not previously been explored in such detail.

Duncan's research contributes to our understanding of language variation and change in US metropolitan areas, which hold a majority of the population. In this way, his work contributes to a broader understanding of how Americans speak. That development and sprawl influence linguistic variation points to a role of urban policy in language use. This work helps us to understand that link better, which may lead to further research that contributes to improved approaches to urban policy.
